ground_truth: Szpilman and the German Captain enter through another set of doors, and the German Captain's boots echo as they come into a spacious room with faint moonlight filtering through the large windows, amidst fallen masonry and broken glass. In the room, there are a couple of chairs and a grand piano in the corner. The German Captain points at the piano, and Szpilman hesitates before limping to it, putting down the tin, and opening the lid. He turns, drags over one of the chairs, and sits as the German Captain stands and watches. Szpilman glances surreptitiously at his hands, then plays Chopin while the German Captain listens, expressionless. The pale moonlight reveals the German Captain to be a handsome, elegant man. After Szpilman finishes playing, the German Captain stares at him, and a moment passes. Szpilman nods, just stares at him, then hesitates, takes the tin, and shuffles past the German Captain towards the door. The German Captain takes out a flashlight, sees a ladder leading up to the loft, and Szpilman climbs it, squeezes into the loft, and looks down at the German Captain, who shines his light on him. Szpilman shows him the tin before quickly going. Szpilman opens the package, finding bread and marmalade, and then finds a tin-opener. Snow falls as the Germans evacuate the villa; men carry out boxes, filing cabinets, desks, papers, and load them into trucks. Szpilman opens the trapdoor to see the German Captain in the attic, carrying a package, and Szpilman faces him as the Captain hands him the package, which Szpilman opens to find several loaves of bread inside. Szpilman shivers with cold, and the German Captain takes off his coat and gives it to him. In the freezing weather with empty streets, Szpilman, wearing the German Captain's coat and under the eiderdown, hears the strange sound of recorded music, recognizing the Polish national anthem as a car with a loudspeaker and Polish national flag comes into view. Astonished and puzzled, he comes to a decision and starts to leave, cautiously trotting down the staircase into the empty hall in his German military overcoat. He goes to the front door, opens it a crack, and cautiously goes out, looking around and hearing the car loudspeaker indistinctly. Hearing the commotion, a woman runs, yelling, towards the field kitchen, as does a man. Szpilman stands and stares, then sees one of the soldiers cock his rifle and fire at him. Szpilman runs while the firing continues, and he bolts into the doorway of a ruined building, peers out, and sees Polish soldiers beginning to surround the building, firing shots and lobbing a grenade or two. Two of the Polish officers stand near the entrance, hearing Szpilman's shouts.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Szpilman and the Teutonic Commander ingress through another pair of portals, and the Teutonic Commander's footwear resounds as they proceed into a capacious chamber with dim moonbeam sifting through the substantial panes, amid toppled brickwork and shattered crystal. Within the chamber, there exist a couple of seats and a grand pianoforte in the corner. The Teutonic Commander indicates the pianoforte, and Szpilman falters before hobbling to it, setting down the can, and lifting the cover. He rotates, pulls over one of the seats, and sits as the Teutonic Commander stands and observes. Szpilman furtively glances at his hands, then performs Chopin while the Teutonic Commander listens, impassive. The wan moonbeam discloses the Teutonic Commander to be a comely, refined individual. After Szpilman concludes performing, the Teutonic Commander gazes at him, and an instant elapses. Szpilman acknowledges, merely gazes at him, then falters, takes the can, and shuffles past the Teutonic Commander towards the portal. The Teutonic Commander extracts a torch, observes a ladder leading up to the garret, and Szpilman ascends it, squeezes into the garret, and looks down at the Teutonic Commander, who illuminates him. Szpilman displays the can before swiftly departing. Szpilman unwraps the parcel, discovering bread and marmalade, and then locates a can-opener. Snow descends as the Germans vacate the villa; men bear out crates, filing cabinets, desks, documents, and load them into lorries. Szpilman opens the hatch to see the Teutonic Commander in the loft, bearing a parcel, and Szpilman confronts him as the Commander hands him the parcel, which Szpilman opens to discover several loaves of bread within. Szpilman shivers with chill, and the Teutonic Commander removes his jacket and gives it to him. In the glacial climate with vacant avenues, Szpilman, donning the Teutonic Commander's jacket and beneath the duvet, hears the peculiar sound of recorded melody, recognizing the Polish national hymn as a vehicle with a loudspeaker and Polish national banner comes into sight. Astonished and perplexed, he reaches a resolution and commences to depart, cautiously trotting down the staircase into the vacant corridor in his Teutonic military overcoat. He proceeds to the entryway, opens it slightly, and cautiously exits, surveying the surroundings and hearing the vehicle loudspeaker indistinctly. Hearing the tumult, a woman rushes, shouting, towards the field kitchen, as does a man. Szpilman stands and gazes, then perceives one of the troopers ready his firearm and discharge at him. Szpilman dashes while the firing persists, and he bolts into the entryway of a demolished structure, peers out, and sees Polish soldiers starting to encircle the structure, discharging shots and tossing a grenade or two. Two of the Polish officers stand near the ingress, hearing Szpilman's cries.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Through another set of doors, Szpilman and the German Captain are entered, and as they are brought into a spacious room with faint moonlight filtering through the large windows, the German Captain's boots echo amidst fallen masonry and broken glass. A couple of chairs and a grand piano are found in the corner of the room. At the piano, the German Captain is pointed, and hesitation is shown by Szpilman before a limp is taken to it, the tin is put down, and the lid is opened by him. He turns, drags over one of the chairs, and sits while the German Captain stands and watches. Surreptitious glances are given by Szpilman at his hands before Chopin is played by him as the German Captain listens, expressionless. The pale moonlight reveals the German Captain to be a handsome, elegant man. After the playing is finished by Szpilman, he is stared at by the German Captain, and a moment passes. A nod is given by Szpilman, he just stares at him, then hesitates, takes the tin, and a shuffle past the German Captain towards the door is made by him. A flashlight is taken out by the German Captain, who sees a ladder leading up to the loft, and it is climbed by Szpilman, who squeezes into the loft and looks down at the German Captain, who shines his light on him. The tin is shown by Szpilman before a quick going is made by him. The package is opened by Szpilman, who finds bread and marmalade, and a tin-opener is then found. As snow falls, the villa is evacuated by the Germans; boxes, filing cabinets, desks, and papers are carried out by men and loaded into trucks. The trapdoor is opened by Szpilman to see the German Captain in the attic, carrying a package, and he is faced by Szpilman as the Captain hands him the package, which, when opened by Szpilman, reveals several loaves of bread inside. Shivering with cold, Szpilman is given the German Captain's coat. In the freezing weather with empty streets, the strange sound of recorded music is heard by Szpilman, who recognizes the Polish national anthem as a car with a loudspeaker and Polish national flag comes into view. Astonishment and puzzlement come to him, and a decision is made to leave, cautiously trotting down the staircase into the empty hall in his German military overcoat. The front door is gone to, opened a crack, and cautiously gone out by him, looking around and hearing the car loudspeaker indistinctly. As the commotion is heard, a woman runs, yelling, towards the field kitchen, as does a man. Standing and staring, Szpilman then sees one of the soldiers cocking his rifle and firing at him. While firing continues, Szpilman runs and bolts into the doorway of a ruined building, peers out, and sees Polish soldiers beginning to surround the building, firing shots and lobbing a grenade or two. Near the entrance stand two of the Polish officers, who hear Szpilman's shouts.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Szpilman and the German Captain enter a spacious room with moonlight filtering through large windows, amidst debris. Inside are a couple of chairs and a piano. The Captain gestures at the piano, Szpilman hesitates, then limps over, sets down a tin, and sits to play Chopin while the Captain watches, expressionless. The moonlight reveals the Captain as handsome and elegant. After finishing, Szpilman nods, takes the tin, and moves toward the door. The Captain uses a flashlight to find a ladder to the loft, where Szpilman climbs and quickly shows the tin. He finds bread and marmalade inside. Snow falls as Germans evacuate the villa, loading boxes and papers into trucks. Szpilman opens the trapdoor, and the Captain hands him a package with bread. Shivering, Szpilman receives the Captain's coat. In the cold, hearing recorded music, Szpilman recognizes the Polish anthem from a car with a loudspeaker and flag. Surprised, he decides to leave and cautiously heads down the staircase wearing the Captain's coat. Outside, a woman and a man run towards a field kitchen. A soldier fires at Szpilman, who runs into a ruined building. He sees Polish soldiers surrounding the building, firing and throwing grenades, and shouts to the officers near the entrance.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Szpilman and the German Captain enter a spacious room, moonlight filtering through windows, amidst debris. A grand piano and chairs are inside. The German Captain points to the piano, and Szpilman limps over, dragging a chair to play Chopin while the Captain watches. The moonlight reveals the German Captain as handsome. Szpilman finishes, nods, takes the tin, and moves to the door. The Captain uses a flashlight, and Szpilman climbs into the loft, showing the tin before leaving. He finds bread and marmalade inside. As snow falls, Germans evacuate the villa with belongings. Szpilman opens the trapdoor, and the Captain hands him a package of bread, giving him his coat. Szpilman, wearing the coat, hears recorded music—the Polish anthem—and decides to leave, cautiously exiting in the coat. He hears a car with the Polish flag and a loudspeaker. A commotion arises, and as a man fires at Szpilman, he runs into a ruined building. Polish soldiers surround the building, firing and throwing grenades, as officers hear Szpilman's shouts.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Szpilman and the German Captain make their way through another set of imposing doors, and the sound of the German Captain’s boots echoing off the hard floor fills the air as they step into a spacious, vast room. The shadows are softened by faint moonlight that gently filters in through the large, towering windows, revealing a scene of tranquility amidst the chaos of fallen masonry and shards of broken glass scattered across the floor. Within this room, a couple of chairs stand alongside a grand piano gracing one of the corners. The German Captain points with an authoritative gesture at the piano, and Szpilman hesitates momentarily before he begins to limp over, placing down the tin he carries and carefully lifting the lid of the piano. He turns his attention, drags over one of the chairs with effort, and sits down as the German Captain stands by, watching attentively. Szpilman casts a surreptitious glance at his hands, then proceeds to play Chopin, while the German Captain listens with an impassive expression. Under the pale moonlight, the German Captain's handsome and elegant features are subtly illuminated. When Szpilman finishes playing, the German Captain continues to stare at him, and a moment of silence passes between them. In acknowledgment, Szpilman nods and simply stares back before he hesitates, retrieves the tin, and shuffles past the German Captain on his way to the door. 

The German Captain then takes out a flashlight, the beam revealing a ladder leading up to the loft. Szpilman climbs up the ladder, squeezes into the loft's confines, and looks down at the German Captain, who directs his light upwards, illuminating Szpilman. Szpilman shows him the tin before quickly moving away. He opens the package he has, discovering bread and marmalade inside, and then finds a tin-opener. Outside, snow begins to fall as the German forces start evacuating the villa; men can be seen carrying boxes, filing cabinets, desks, and papers, loading them efficiently into waiting trucks. Szpilman opens the trapdoor cautiously and sees the German Captain in the attic, carrying a package. Szpilman stands facing him as the Captain hands him the package, which he eagerly opens to discover several loaves of bread inside. Shivering from the biting cold, Szpilman watches as the German Captain removes his own coat and generously gives it to him. 

In the freezing, desolate weather, with the streets eerily empty and devoid of life, Szpilman finds himself wearing the German Captain’s coat and resting under the warmth of an eiderdown. Suddenly, he hears the strange and unexpected sound of recorded music playing, and he recognizes it as the Polish national anthem. He notices a car with a loudspeaker and a Polish national flag coming into view, which astonishes and puzzles him. After contemplating for a moment, he arrives at a decision and begins to cautiously make his way out, carefully trotting down the staircase into the vast emptiness of the hall, clad in the German military overcoat. He approaches the front door, opens it a crack, and cautiously steps out, looking around attentively and hearing the car's loudspeaker in the distance, its message indistinct. Amidst the commotion, a woman starts running, yelling towards the field kitchen, and a man follows her swiftly. Szpilman stands still, staring, then spots one of the soldiers who suddenly cocks his rifle and fires at him. In a panic, Szpilman runs as the firing continues, bolting into the safety of a doorway of a nearby ruined building. He peers cautiously out and sees Polish soldiers beginning to surround the building, strategically firing shots and tossing a grenade or two. Two of the Polish officers stand alert near the entrance, straining to hear Szpilman’s shouts.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Szpilman and the German Captain proceed together as they make their way through yet another set of heavy, imposing doors. The sound of the German Captain’s boots echoes sharply, reverberating off the hard, cold floor and filling the air with a rhythmic beat as they step into a spacious and vast room. This large room is bathed in softened shadows, gently illuminated by the faint moonlight that streams in through the large, towering windows. This muted light reveals a scene of almost surreal tranquility amidst the chaos of fallen masonry and shards of broken glass that are scattered haphazardly across the floor. Within the expansive room, a couple of chairs stand silently alongside a grand piano that graces one of the corners with its imposing presence. The German Captain, with an authoritative and commanding gesture, points at the piano, prompting Szpilman to hesitate momentarily. After a brief pause, he limps over, placing down the tin he carries and carefully lifting the lid of the piano. With focused attention, he drags over one of the chairs with great effort and sits down, while the German Captain stands by, watching him with keen interest and an attentive gaze. Szpilman casts a surreptitious glance at his hands, then proceeds to play Chopin, while the German Captain listens with an expression that remains impassive. Under the gentle glow of the pale moonlight, the German Captain's handsome and elegant features are subtly illuminated. When Szpilman finishes playing, the German Captain continues to stare at him intently, and a moment of silence passes between them. In acknowledgment, Szpilman nods briefly and stares back before he hesitates, retrieves the tin, and shuffles past the German Captain as he makes his way towards the door. 

At this point, the German Captain takes out a flashlight, the beam of light revealing a ladder leading up to the loft. Szpilman begins to climb up the ladder, squeezing himself into the narrow confines of the loft, and looks down at the German Captain, who directs his light upwards, illuminating Szpilman in the process. Szpilman shows him the tin before quickly moving away. He proceeds to open the package he has, discovering bread and marmalade inside, and then manages to find a tin-opener. Outside, snow starts to fall gently as the German forces commence evacuating the villa; men are seen busily carrying boxes, filing cabinets, desks, and papers, loading them with precision and efficiency into the waiting trucks. Szpilman cautiously opens the trapdoor and sees the German Captain standing in the attic, carrying a package. Szpilman stands facing him as the Captain hands him the package, which he eagerly opens to discover several loaves of bread inside. Shivering from the biting cold, Szpilman watches as the German Captain removes his own coat and generously hands it over to him. 

Amidst the freezing, desolate weather, with the streets eerily empty and devoid of life, Szpilman finds himself wearing the German Captain’s coat and resting under the comforting warmth of an eiderdown. Suddenly, he hears the strange and unexpected sound of recorded music playing, and he recognizes it as none other than the Polish national anthem. He notices a car equipped with a loudspeaker and bearing a Polish national flag coming into view, which both astonishes and puzzles him greatly. After contemplating the situation for a moment, he arrives at a decision and begins to cautiously make his way out, carefully trotting down the staircase into the vast emptiness of the hall, all the while clad in the German military overcoat. He approaches the front door, opens it just a crack, and steps out cautiously, looking around with a sharp eye and hearing the car's loudspeaker in the distance, its message indistinct and unclear. Amidst the commotion, a woman suddenly starts running, yelling towards the field kitchen, and a man quickly follows her. Szpilman stands still, staring in surprise, and then spots one of the soldiers who suddenly cocks his rifle and fires at him. In a surge of panic, Szpilman runs frantically as the firing continues, bolting into the safety of a doorway of a nearby ruined building. He peers cautiously out and sees Polish soldiers beginning to strategically surround the building, expertly firing shots and tossing a grenade or two. Two of the Polish officers stand alert near the entrance, straining to hear Szpilman’s shouts above the noise.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Szpilman and the German Captain enter through another set of doors, with the Captain's boots echoing in the spacious room. The dim moonlight filters through large windows, casting a pale glow on the scene of fallen masonry and broken glass scattered across the floor. Within this setting are a couple of chairs and a grand piano tucked into one corner. The German Captain points decisively at the piano, prompting Szpilman to hesitate momentarily before he limps over to it. As he reaches the piano, he places the tin down with care, opens the lid with measured movements, and turns around to drag one of the chairs closer to the piano. Szpilman seats himself while the German Captain remains standing, observing without expression. Szpilman steals a quick, surreptitious glance at his hands before he begins to play Chopin, his fingers moving deftly over the keys as the German Captain listens, remaining impassive. The gentle illumination from the moonlight reveals the German Captain's features, showing him to be a handsome and elegantly composed man. Once Szpilman concludes his performance, the German Captain fixes his gaze on him, creating a moment of silent connection between them. Szpilman offers a nod but continues to stare, before he hesitates, retrieves the tin, and shuffles past the Captain towards the door. The German Captain produces a flashlight, its beam falling on a ladder that leads up to a loft. Szpilman begins to climb this ladder, squeezing into the confined space of the loft and glancing down at the German Captain, who shines the flashlight upon him. Szpilman displays the tin briefly before quickly moving away. Upon opening the package, he discovers bread and marmalade, followed by a tin-opener. Outside, snow gently falls as the Germans proceed to evacuate the villa, with men busily carrying out boxes, filing cabinets, desks, and papers, loading them meticulously into waiting trucks. Szpilman cautiously opens the trapdoor to observe the German Captain in the attic, carrying a package. Facing him, Szpilman watches as the Captain hands him the package, which he promptly opens to reveal several loaves of bread inside. Shivering from the biting cold, Szpilman gratefully accepts the German Captain's coat as it is offered to him. Enveloped in the freezing weather, with streets lying empty, Szpilman finds himself wrapped in the German Captain's coat and under an eiderdown, when he is startled by the strange sound of recorded music. Recognizing the melody as the Polish national anthem, he looks out to see a car equipped with a loudspeaker and adorned with the Polish national flag coming into view. Astonished and bewildered by the sight, he reaches a decision and prepares to leave, cautiously descending the staircase into the deserted hall while clad in the German military overcoat. He makes his way to the front door, nudging it open slightly to peer outside with caution. As he steps out, he remains alert, ears attuned to the indistinct blare of the car loudspeaker. The commotion draws a woman, who sprints and yells towards the field kitchen, followed closely by a man. Szpilman pauses to stand and stare, witnessing one of the soldiers cock his rifle and fire at him. Startled, Szpilman sprints away as the firing continues, rushing into the doorway of a ruined building. He peeks out, observing the Polish soldiers as they begin to encircle the building, their weapons discharging and grenades being lobbed. Two of the Polish officers take positions near the entrance, attentively listening to Szpilman's shouts for recognition.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Szpilman and the German Captain enter a spacious, moonlit room filled with debris, where the Captain gestures towards a grand piano. Szpilman limps over, positions a chair, and begins to play Chopin as the German Captain listens without expression. The moonlight reveals the Captain's handsome, elegant features. After the performance, Szpilman nods at the Captain, collects his belongings, and moves past him toward the door. As the Captain illuminates a ladder with a flashlight, Szpilman climbs into the loft and shows him a tin before departing. Discovering bread and marmalade inside, Szpilman begins to eat as the Germans evacuate the villa, loading trucks with various items. Later, the German Captain hands Szpilman a package containing several loaves of bread and gives him his coat to combat the cold. Wearing the coat, Szpilman hears the Polish national anthem and sees a car with a loudspeaker and flag. He decides to leave, cautiously descending the stairs in the German military overcoat. Outside, amidst the empty streets, he hears indistinct announcements from the car. Upon hearing commotion, a woman and a man run toward a field kitchen. Szpilman is targeted by a soldier who fires at him, prompting him to flee into a ruined building. From there, he observes Polish soldiers surrounding the area, firing shots and tossing grenades, as two officers near the entrance hear his shouts.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Szpilman and the German Captain enter through another set of doors, and the German Captain's boots echo as they come into a spacious room with faint moonlight filtering through the large windows, remnants of Warsaw's once-grand architecture now amidst fallen masonry and broken glass. In the room, there are a couple of chairs and a grand piano in the corner, a symbol of cultural resilience during the war. The German Captain points at the piano, and Szpilman, a Jewish pianist hiding in Warsaw to escape Nazi persecution, hesitates before limping to it, putting down the tin, and opening the lid. He turns, drags over one of the chairs, and sits as the German Captain stands and watches. Szpilman glances surreptitiously at his hands, then plays Chopin, the famous Polish composer whose works were often associated with national pride, while the German Captain listens, expressionless. The pale moonlight reveals the German Captain to be a handsome, elegant man, a striking contrast to the chaos surrounding them. After Szpilman finishes playing, the German Captain, likely conflicted between duty and compassion, stares at him, and a moment passes. Szpilman nods, just stares at him, then hesitates, takes the tin, and shuffles past the German Captain towards the door. The German Captain takes out a flashlight, sees a ladder leading up to the loft where Szpilman has been hiding from Nazi roundups, and Szpilman climbs it, squeezes into the loft, and looks down at the German Captain, who shines his light on him. Szpilman shows him the tin before quickly going. Szpilman opens the package, finding bread and marmalade, precious food items during war rationing, and then finds a tin-opener. Snow falls as the Germans evacuate the villa in Warsaw; men carry out boxes, filing cabinets, desks, papers, and load them into trucks, evidence of the occupying forces' withdrawal. Szpilman opens the trapdoor to see the German Captain in the attic, carrying a package, and Szpilman faces him as the Captain hands him the package, which Szpilman opens to find several loaves of bread inside, a lifesaving gift in a time of scarcity. Szpilman shivers with cold, and the German Captain takes off his coat and gives it to him, an act of human kindness during the brutal winter. In the freezing weather with empty streets, Szpilman, wearing the German Captain's coat and under the eiderdown, hears the strange sound of recorded music, recognizing the Polish national anthem, a symbol of hope and resistance, as a car with a loudspeaker and Polish national flag comes into view, signaling liberation. Astonished and puzzled, he comes to a decision and starts to leave, cautiously trotting down the staircase into the empty hall in his German military overcoat. He goes to the front door, opens it a crack, and cautiously goes out, looking around and hearing the car loudspeaker indistinctly. Hearing the commotion, a woman runs, yelling, towards the field kitchen, a place set up to provide meals for soldiers, as does a man. Szpilman stands and stares, then sees one of the soldiers cock his rifle and fire at him, reminding him of the constant danger in war-torn Warsaw. Szpilman runs while the firing continues, and he bolts into the doorway of a ruined building, evidence of the widespread destruction in the city, peers out, and sees Polish soldiers beginning to surround the building, firing shots and lobbing a grenade or two, reclaiming their city from the occupiers. Two of the Polish officers stand near the entrance, hearing Szpilman's shouts, a desperate cry in the midst of chaos.

In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Snow falls as the Germans evacuate the villa. men carry out boxes filing cabinets desks papers and load them into trucks. Szpilman opens the trapdoor to see the German Captain in the attic carrying a package and Szpilman faces him as the Captain hands him the package which Szpilman opens to find several loaves of bread inside. Szpilman shivers with cold and the German Captain takes off his coat and gives it to him. In the freezing weather with empty streets Szpilman wearing the German Captain's coat and under the eiderdown hears the strange sound of recorded music recognizing the Polish national anthem as a car with a loudspeaker and Polish national flag comes into view. Astonished and puzzled he comes to a decision and starts to leave cautiously trotting down the staircase into the empty hall in his German military overcoat. He goes to the front door opens it a crack and cautiously goes out looking around and hearing the car loudspeaker indistinctly. Hearing the commotion a woman runs yelling towards the field kitchen as does a man. Szpilman stands and stares then sees one of the soldiers cock his rifle and fire at him. Szpilman runs while the firing continues and he bolts into the doorway of a ruined building peers out and sees Polish soldiers beginning to surround the building firing shots and lobbing a grenade or two. Two of the Polish officers stand near the entrance hearing Szpilman's shouts.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: Szpilman and the German Captain enter through another set of doors and the German Captain's boots echo as they come into a spacious room with faint moonlight filtering through the large windows amidst fallen masonry and broken glass. In the room there are a couple of chairs and a grand piano in the corner. The German Captain points at the piano and Szpilman hesitates before limping to it putting down the tin and opening the lid. He turns drags over one of the chairs and sits as the German Captain stands and watches. Szpilman glances surreptitiously at his hands then plays Chopin while the German Captain listens expressionless. The pale moonlight reveals the German Captain to be a handsome elegant man. He goes to the front door opens it a crack and cautiously goes out looking around and hearing the car loudspeaker indistinctly. Hearing the commotion a woman runs yelling towards the field kitchen as does a man. Szpilman stands and stares then sees one of the soldiers cock his rifle and fire at him. Szpilman runs while the firing continues and he bolts into the doorway of a ruined building peers out and sees Polish soldiers beginning to surround the building firing shots and lobbing a grenade or two. Two of the Polish officers stand near the entrance hearing Szpilman's shouts.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: Szpilman and the German Captain enter through another set of doors and the German Captain's boots echo as they come into a spacious room with faint moonlight filtering through the large windows amidst fallen masonry and broken glass. In the room there are a couple of chairs and a grand piano in the corner. The German Captain points at the piano and Szpilman hesitates before limping to it putting down the tin and opening the lid. Szpilman runs while the firing continues and he bolts into the doorway of a ruined building peers out and sees Polish soldiers beginning to surround the building firing shots and lobbing a grenade or two. Two of the Polish officers stand near the entrance hearing Szpilman's shouts.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Mandrake and the Italian Gardener glide through another pair of curtains, and the Italian Gardener's sandals hum as they arrive into a cramped closet with bright starlight trickling through the narrow vents, amidst scattered paper and rusted cans. Inside the closet, there are a few tables and a tiny harp in the nook. The Italian Gardener gestures at the harp, and Mandrake falters before tiptoeing to it, setting down the basket, and swinging the cover. He spins, pulls over one of the tables, and lounges as the Italian Gardener leans and observes. Mandrake peeks sheepishly at his feet, then strums Debussy while the Italian Gardener listens, unmoved. The bright starlight reveals the Italian Gardener to be a rugged, disheveled woman. After Mandrake concludes strumming, the Italian Gardener gazes at him, and a silence stretches. Mandrake bows, simply gazes at her, then falters, retrieves the basket, and trundles past the Italian Gardener towards the curtain. The Italian Gardener extracts a candle, notices a rope trailing up to the turret, and Mandrake scales it, squeezes into the turret, and gazes down at the Italian Gardener, who flicks his beam on him. Mandrake shows him the basket before hastily leaving. Mandrake unties the parcel, discovering apples and honey, and then discovers a knife. Rain falls as the Italians vacate the cottage; figures haul out paintings, file folders, chairs, scripts, and stow them into wagons. Mandrake unlatches the skylight to spot the Italian Gardener in the loft, holding a parcel, and Mandrake faces her as the Gardener passes him the parcel, which Mandrake unties to find several crates of apples inside. Mandrake quivers with heat, and the Italian Gardener removes his scarf and hands it to him. In the sweltering climate with bustling roads, Mandrake, wearing the Italian Gardener's scarf and under the umbrella, catches the familiar tune of live jazz, recognizing the Swiss folk song as a bicycle with a music box and Swiss regional banner rolls into sight. Flabbergasted and bewildered, he reaches a conclusion and starts to wander, meticulously tiptoeing down the corridor into the bustling lounge in his Italian ballroom cloak. He ventures to the side gate, swings it open a notch, and meticulously steps out, glancing around and catching the music box vaguely. Hearing the ruckus, a child dashes, shouting, towards the tea cart, as does an elder. Mandrake pauses and gawks, then watches one of the cooks swing his knife and toss at him. Mandrake dashes while the tossing persists, and he dives into the window of a collapsed shed, gazes out, and sees Swiss bakers beginning to encircle the shed, tossing stones and flipping a torch or two. Two of the Swiss chefs stand near the façade, hearing Mandrake's calls.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Szpilman and a German Captain enter a room with moonlight streaming through broken windows, revealing a piano. The Captain points to the piano, and Szpilman plays Chopin while the Captain listens silently. After he finishes, Szpilman collects his belongings and climbs to a loft as the Captain shines a flashlight on him. Szpilman finds bread and marmalade in a package. Later, as Germans evacuate, Szpilman receives a coat and bread from the Captain. Wearing the coat, Szpilman ventures into the empty streets and hears the Polish national anthem from a passing car. Deciding to leave, he cautiously exits but is shot at by soldiers. He takes cover in a ruined building and sees Polish soldiers surrounding it. Hearing Szpilman's shouts, two Polish officers approach.
